close_symbols: OS_FdSet (definition of member object_ids: element type and array length)
explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required for checking MISRA ‘controlling expressions shall not be invariant’: 

- BUGCHECK
  - The macro may expand to code that contains its own controlling expression(s). Its expansion/semantics determine whether it could introduce an invariant controlling expression (or alter control flow) when called as BUGCHECK(Set != NULL, false). Need the definition to assess any implicit control statements and whether they are invariant.

- OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex
  - The if-condition uses its return (return_code != OS_SUCCESS). To determine whether that controlling expression can be invariant we must know the function contract/implementation: possible return values, whether the return depends on the objid input, and whether it guarantees to set local_id. Also its side-effects (writes to local_id) affect subsequent indexing/shift expressions.

- OS_SUCCESS
  - The comparison target in the controlling expression. Its value/meaning is needed to determine if the comparison can ever be false/true for varying inputs (i.e. whether the expression could be invariant).

- OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM
  - Passed into OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex; the mapping of objid→return_code/local_id may depend on this constant. Knowing its value/semantics is necessary to evaluate whether the return value is input-dependent or constant for all calls.

- OS_FdSet (definition of member object_ids: element type and array length)
  - The final returned expression indexes and shifts object_ids[local_id >> 3]. To ensure no undefined behaviour and to reason about invariance of any implicitly used control constructs, we need the element type (e.g., uint8_t) and the array length to ensure local_id>>3 is an in-range non-negative index and that the bit-shift operations are well-defined.

- osal_index_t (typedef: signedness/width)
  - local_id is of this type. The signedness and width determine semantics of right-shift (implementation-defined for signed), index validity, and whether local_id can be negative. If local_id could be negative, the code may rely on UB/implementation-defined behaviour, or cause invariant outcomes; so the typedef is required to reason about the controlling expression and subsequent operations.

- osal_id_t (typedef and valid domain)
  - The nature/range of the input objid may influence whether OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex can return different values. To decide if the controlling expression return_code != OS_SUCCESS can be invariant, we must know the domain/interpretation of objid (valid/invalid values).

(Other symbols in the static call graph such as UT_... or OS_printf are not required to determine whether the controlling expressions in this function are invariant.)
